title: Mercury square Venus
summary: A tension between logic and values. What sounds reasonable may not feel satisfying, and what feels right may be hard to articulate. The opportunity is to clarify priorities without smoothing over real differences.

meaning.headline: What makes sense and what feels right may diverge.

frames.text: Mercury–Venus squares highlight friction between reasoning and values, making compromises harder to ignore.
This aspect surfaces where communication choices don’t fully align with personal or relational priorities.
Conversations may feel slightly off even when they are polite or logical.
Decisions can stall when preference and practicality compete.
This guarantees conflict, misunderstanding, or hurt feelings.

frictions: Saying what’s reasonable instead of what’s true
Avoiding clarity to keep things pleasant
Feeling dissatisfied after seemingly productive conversations
opportunities: Clarifying which values matter most in communication
Refining agreements to better reflect priorities

do: Name the value at stake before negotiating details.
Distinguish between being agreeable and being aligned.
Allow some discomfort in honest conversations.
Revisit decisions that feel logically sound but emotionally thin.
avoid: Smoothing over differences to move faster
Treating discomfort as a failure of communication

reusable_lines.text: Clarity improves when values are named, not assumed.
Honest alignment matters more than sounding agreeable.

allowed_framing: Contextual framing: 'if conversations or decisions feel strained…'

sources: Mercury–Venus square as cognition/value tension archetype
